name: Dubrovnik
fun_fact: Fun fact: Dubrovnik's black risotto (crni ri≈æot) may have actually originated here during Venetian rule before spreading to Venice, where it's known as risotto nero di sepia. The oldest recorded recipe for pa≈°ticada dates to 15th century Dubrovnik!

hero_dishes.name: Crni Ri≈æot (Black Risotto)
hero_dishes.description: A striking dark risotto colored with squid ink, often containing squid, mussels, clams, and other shellfish. The rice absorbs the deep, briny flavor of the ink and seafood.
hero_dishes.origin_story: Some sources suggest this dish originated in Dubrovnik while it was under Venetian rule (before spreading to Venice). The dramatic black color comes from cuttlefish or squid ink, creating a dish that's as visually stunning as it is delicious.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Gverovic Orsan (Shtikovica 43) is well-loved by both locals and tourists for its wonderful black risotto. Poklisar, right on Dubrovnik's Old Town harbor, serves it with live music. Restaurant Kopun (Polj R Bo≈°koviƒáa 7) expertly prepares black risotto with local ingredients.

hero_dishes.name: Pa≈°ticada (Dalmatinska Pa≈°ticada)
hero_dishes.description: Often called the 'queen of Dalmatian cuisine' - beef marinated in vinegar and spices, then slow-cooked until meltingly tender. Served with gnocchi or homemade pasta.
hero_dishes.origin_story: A meal reserved for important functions and celebrations, with the oldest recorded recipe traced to 15th century Dubrovnik. This dish originates in Dalmatia and represents the pinnacle of Croatian cooking tradition, requiring patience and skill.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konavoski Dvori in the lush Konavle valley serves rich, hearty pa≈°ticada made the proper traditional way. Restaurant Kopun in Old Town also serves this traditional dish. Note: often needs to be ordered in advance due to lengthy preparation.

hero_dishes.name: Peka
hero_dishes.description: A mega one-pot feast containing meat, seafood, and vegetables cooked under a bell-shaped lidded pot covered in hot coals. This unique cooking method is part of Croatian life.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional Dalmatian cooking method has been used for generations, with the bell-shaped lid and hot coals creating an oven-like environment that slowly roasts and steams the ingredients.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Konoba Dubrava (situated in Bosanka above Dubrovnik) is one of the top spots for peka. The rustic konoba atmosphere is homely, portions are generous, and flavors unforgettable. Must be ordered in advance at most restaurants.

hero_dishes.name: Buzara
hero_dishes.description: A Dalmatian style of cooking seafood (typically mussels or prawns) in white wine, garlic, parsley, olive oil, and breadcrumbs.
hero_dishes.origin_story: This traditional Adriatic preparation highlights the freshness of local seafood with simple Mediterranean flavors.
hero_dishes.where_to_find: Available at most seafood restaurants in Old Town and along the harbor.

signature_drinks.name: Rozulin (Rose Liqueur)
signature_drinks.description: A traditional rose-flavored liqueur used in Dubrovnik's famous rozata dessert, but also enjoyed on its own.
signature_drinks.how_locals_drink_it: Often served as a digestif after meals, or used to flavor the city's signature dessert.
